org.sakaiproject.genericdao.springjdbc
Class JdbcGenericDao

java.lang.Object
  org.springframework.dao.support.DaoSupport
      org.springframework.jdbc.core.support.JdbcDaoSupport
          org.sakaiproject.genericdao.springjdbc.JdbcGenericDao
All Implemented Interfaces:
GenericDao, BasicModifier, InitializingBean
Direct Known Subclasses:
JdbcBasicGenericDao
public class JdbcGenericDao
extends JdbcDaoSupport
implements GenericDao

A Spring JDBC (http://hibernate.org/) based implementation of GenericDao which can be extended to add more specialized DAO methods.

Note: This implementation is so simple it is unlikely to be useful

See the overview for installation/usage tips.

Author:
Aaron Zeckoski (azeckoski@gmail.com)

 boolean closeConnection()
          Allows a developer to do a manual release of the connection, this will cause a new connection to be obtained the next time a method is executed, anything not yet committed for this connection will be rolled back and lost, normally if you are using a DataSource which pools connections then you do not need to worry about this too much, just do it at the end of your work unit
 boolean commitTransaction()
          This will do a commit on the current DB Connection on this thread, allows the developer to force a commit immediately
Remember to close your connection if you are completely done with it

 String getUpdateTemplate(Class<?> type)
           
protected  String handleTypeReplacements(Class<?> type, String ddl)
          Handle the replacements of DDL constants in the supplied DDL with real values based on the supplied type
The following keys will be replaced automatically:
{TABLENAME} - the value returned by #getTableName()
{ID} - the column name of the unique identifier
{TABLENAME:org.domain.MyClass} - the value returned by #getTableName() for the persistent type MyClass
{ID:org.domain.MyClass} - the column name of the unique identifier for the persistent type MyClass
{COLUMNNAME:propertyName} - the column name which maps to the propertyName
{IDSEQNAME} - (Oracle) a sequence name will be generated and inserted based on the table name for use in generating IDs, if you want to specify your own sequence name then you will lose the ability to have the ID inserted into newly created objects
protected  void initCaches()
          Creates all the caches for the current set of persistent types, this should be called in the init for the generic dao being used after persistent classes are loaded

          Allows control over whether the DDL should be committed after each statement as it is read in, this should probably be disabled if you are using a transaction manager and should be enabled if you are managing your own transactions

          Force the current database translator to be this one
 void setDatabaseType(String databaseType)
          This should be set to the type of database being used and determines which DDL to run when creating the tables, defaults to DataMapper.DBTYPE_HSQLDB "HSQLDB", will fixup case as needed
 void setDataMappers(List<DataMapper> dataMappers)
          This tells the DAO about your persistent classes and their associated tables, it is the major configuration path for the DAO
 void setInterceptor(DaoOperationInterceptor interceptor)
          Makes the given interceptor the only active interceptor, removes all others and adds only this one
 void setNonSpringDataSource(DataSource dataSource)
          This is a special case DataSource setter method which will wrap the DataSource, you must use this in the case where the DataSource you are using is not a Spring controlled on SmartDataSource, this will wrap the spring DataSource automatically so that the auto-commit and manual transactions will work, without this wrapper your connections will be closed after each jdbcTemplate method runs and nothing will ever be committed (unless the connection is set to auto-commit)
WARNING: if you use this then you are responsible for committing TXs and closing your connections using the closeConnection() and commitTransaction() or rollbackTransaction() methods
Is not thread-bound
 void setNonSpringDataSource(DataSource dataSource, boolean threadBound)
          This is a special case DataSource setter method which will wrap the DataSource, you must use this in the case where the DataSource you are using is not a Spring controlled on SmartDataSource, this will wrap the spring DataSource automatically so that the auto-commit and manual transactions will work, without this wrapper your connections will be closed after each jdbcTemplate method runs and nothing will ever be committed (unless the connection is set to auto-commit)
WARNING: if you use this then you are responsible for committing TXs and closing your connections using the closeConnection() and commitTransaction() or rollbackTransaction() methods
 void setRequiredSettings(DataSource dataSource, boolean threadBoundDataSource, String databaseType, boolean autoDDL, boolean autoCommitDDL, DataMapper[] dataMappers)
          Set all required settings for running the DAO, can be used in the cases where using the complete constructor is inconvenient
This does not actually start the DAO, run startup() to start it
Note that this will be started automatically by Spring if this is created as a Spring bean, no actions are necessary and setting an init method is not needed
 void setShowSQL(boolean showSQL)
          Enable SQL debugging which will show all SQL statements and DDL statements being executed by printing them out
 void startup()
          Starts the DAO using the settings that have been pushed into it so far
There is no need to trigger this if it is being controlled by spring as spring will call initDao() automatically which calls this method
 void update(Object object)
          Updates the object (object must already exist in persistent storage)

showSQL

protected boolean showSQL
Constructor Detail

JdbcGenericDao

public JdbcGenericDao()
Default constructor - does nothing and leaves the object in an incomplete state, you need to at least set the following: JdbcDaoSupport.setDataSource(DataSource)
setAutoDDL(boolean)
setAutoCommitDDL(boolean)
setDatabaseType(String)
setDataMappers(List)

This does not actually start the DAO, run startup() to start it
Note that this will be started automatically by Spring if this is created as a Spring bean, no actions are necessary and setting an init method is not needed

JdbcGenericDao

public JdbcGenericDao(DataSource dataSource,
                      boolean threadBoundDataSource,
                      String databaseType,
                      boolean autoDDL,
                      boolean autoCommitDDL,
                      DataMapper[] dataMappers)
Complete constructor, sets all required values for running the DAO, does not actually start the DAO, run startup() to start it
Note that this will be started automatically by Spring if this is created as a Spring bean, no actions are necessary and setting an init method is not needed

Parameters:
dataSource - the DataSource to use with this DAO
threadBoundDataSource - if true then the DataSource will be bound to threads and only unbound and closed when closeConnection() is called, otherwise a new DataSource is obtained each time, this has no effect if the DataSource is a Spring DataSource
databaseType - the databaseType that this DAO is connecting to (use constants in DatabaseTranslator)
autoDDL - if true then DDL is executed on DAO startup (can be run manually if desired)
autoCommitDDL - if true then commit is executed after each DDL file is executed, if false then you need a TX manager to do this for you
dataMappers - the data mappers which map this DAO to the tables

public void setDatabaseType(String databaseType)
This should be set to the type of database being used and determines which DDL to run when creating the tables, defaults to DataMapper.DBTYPE_HSQLDB "HSQLDB", will fixup case as needed

setAutoCommitDDL

public void setAutoCommitDDL(boolean autoCommitDDL)
Allows control over whether the DDL should be committed after each statement as it is read in, this should probably be disabled if you are using a transaction manager and should be enabled if you are managing your own transactions

Parameters:
autoCommitDDL - true to enable auto commits on DDL excecution

isAutoCommitOperations

public boolean isAutoCommitOperations()
Returns:
true if automatic commit is enabled for all generic DAO write operations

setAutoCommitOperations

public void setAutoCommitOperations(boolean autoCommitOperations)
Allows control over whether the DAO should do automatic commits for all generic DAO write operations

Parameters:
autoCommitOperations - true to enable automatic commits for all generic dao operations, this should be false if you are using a transaction manager

setNonSpringDataSource

public void setNonSpringDataSource(DataSource dataSource)
This is a special case DataSource setter method which will wrap the DataSource, you must use this in the case where the DataSource you are using is not a Spring controlled on SmartDataSource, this will wrap the spring DataSource automatically so that the auto-commit and manual transactions will work, without this wrapper your connections will be closed after each jdbcTemplate method runs and nothing will ever be committed (unless the connection is set to auto-commit)
WARNING: if you use this then you are responsible for committing TXs and closing your connections using the closeConnection() and commitTransaction() or rollbackTransaction() methods
Is not thread-bound

Parameters:
dataSource - any non-spring DataSource
See Also:
setNonSpringDataSource(DataSource, boolean)

setNonSpringDataSource

public void setNonSpringDataSource(DataSource dataSource,
                                   boolean threadBound)
This is a special case DataSource setter method which will wrap the DataSource, you must use this in the case where the DataSource you are using is not a Spring controlled on SmartDataSource, this will wrap the spring DataSource automatically so that the auto-commit and manual transactions will work, without this wrapper your connections will be closed after each jdbcTemplate method runs and nothing will ever be committed (unless the connection is set to auto-commit)
WARNING: if you use this then you are responsible for committing TXs and closing your connections using the closeConnection() and commitTransaction() or rollbackTransaction() methods

Parameters:
dataSource - any non-spring DataSource
threadBound - if true then the connections will be thread-bound and only one returned for the current thread no matter how many times getConnection is called, if false then they will return a new connection for each call

setDataMappers

public void setDataMappers(List<DataMapper> dataMappers)
This tells the DAO about your persistent classes and their associated tables, it is the major configuration path for the DAO

Parameters:
dataMappers - a list of all DataMappers that this DAO uses, ideally this is no more than a few per DAO but it should include all tables which are directly linked

Set all required settings for running the DAO, can be used in the cases where using the complete constructor is inconvenient
This does not actually start the DAO, run startup() to start it
Note that this will be started automatically by Spring if this is created as a Spring bean, no actions are necessary and setting an init method is not needed

Parameters:
dataSource - the DataSource to use with this DAO
threadBoundDataSource - if true then the DataSource will be bound to threads and only unbound and closed when closeConnection() is called, otherwise a new DataSource is obtained each time, this has no effect if the DataSource is a Spring DataSource
databaseType - the databaseType that this DAO is connecting to (use constants in DatabaseTranslator)
autoDDL - if true then DDL is executed on DAO startup (can be run manually if desired)
autoCommitDDL - if true then commit is executed after each DDL file is executed, if false then you need a TX manager to do this for you
dataMappers - the data mappers which map this DAO to the tables

executeDDL

public void executeDDL(InputStream sqlDDL)
Execute a DDL (database definition language) script, this will execute a set of DDL commands which are fed in via an InputStream
The first non-comment ('--') line will be run, and if successful, all other non-comment lines will be run. SQL statements may be on multiple lines but must have ';' terminators.

NOTE: The script should be located in the current ClassLoader, in other words, it must be a visible resource that is packaged with the code that is running this method
Recommended (Example) usage:
1) Place the script into the src folder of your service impl project like so: impl/src/sql/oracle/myscript.sql
2) Load the sql files into the jar by setting up the maven pom like so: <resources> ... <resource> <directory>${basedir}/src/sql</directory> <includes> <include>** /*.sql</include> </includes> </resource> ... </resources> Note: remove the extra space between "**" and "/*.sql"
3) Execute the ddl script in the init method of your DAO (when it first starts up): ClassLoader loader = this.getClass().getClassLoader();
String ddlResource = getDatabaseType() + "/myscript.sql";
InputStream stream = loader.getResourceAsStream(ddlResource);
executeDDL(stream);

Parameters:
sqlDDL - the sql ddl commands to execute
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if ddl is invalid and cannot be executed

makeSQL

protected String makeSQL(String sqlTemplate,
                         String tableName,
                         String... replacements)
Make SQL from a template

Parameters:
sqlTemplate - pass in an SQL template (one of the BASIC_* ones or make your own), the replacement names will be replaced with the replacement values
tableName - the name of the table for this SQL
replacements - a sequence of replacement names (probably #COLUMNS, #WHERE, etc.) and values, alternating like so: name,value,name,value
Returns:
the SQL with all replacements made

handleTypeReplacements

protected String handleTypeReplacements(Class<?> type,
                                        String ddl)
Handle the replacements of DDL constants in the supplied DDL with real values based on the supplied type
The following keys will be replaced automatically:
{TABLENAME} - the value returned by #getTableName()
{ID} - the column name of the unique identifier
{TABLENAME:org.domain.MyClass} - the value returned by #getTableName() for the persistent type MyClass
{ID:org.domain.MyClass} - the column name of the unique identifier for the persistent type MyClass
{COLUMNNAME:propertyName} - the column name which maps to the propertyName
{IDSEQNAME} - (Oracle) a sequence name will be generated and inserted based on the table name for use in generating IDs, if you want to specify your own sequence name then you will lose the ability to have the ID inserted into newly created objects

Parameters:
type - a persistent class type
ddl - database definition statements (can also be SQL)
Returns:
the DDL string with the {vars} replaced

makeComparisonSQL

protected String makeComparisonSQL(String column,
                                   int comparisonConstant,
                                   Object value)
Create comparison SQL but converts the value object to a string

Parameters:
column - the name of a database column
comparisonConstant - the comparison constant (e.g. EQUALS)
value - the value to compare the property to
Returns:
a string representing the SQL snippet (e.g. propA = ?)

makeComparisonSQL

protected String makeComparisonSQL(List<Object> params,
                                   String column,
                                   int comparisonConstant,
                                   Object value)
Parameters:
params - a set of params to add this value to
column - the name of a database column
comparisonConstant - the comparison constant (e.g. EQUALS)
value - the value to compare the property to
Returns:
a string representing the SQL snippet (e.g. propA = ?)

commitTransaction

public boolean commitTransaction()
This will do a commit on the current DB Connection on this thread, allows the developer to force a commit immediately
Remember to close your connection if you are completely done with it

Returns:
true if it committed successfully

rollbackTransaction

public boolean rollbackTransaction()
This will do a rollback on the DB Connection on this thread, allows the developer to force an immediate rollback
Remember to close your connection if you are completely done with it

Returns:
true if the rollback executed successfully

closeConnection

public boolean closeConnection()
Allows a developer to do a manual release of the connection, this will cause a new connection to be obtained the next time a method is executed, anything not yet committed for this connection will be rolled back and lost, normally if you are using a DataSource which pools connections then you do not need to worry about this too much, just do it at the end of your work unit

Returns:
true if the connection was closed

getIdProperty

public String getIdProperty(Class<?> type)
Description copied from interface: GenericDao
Get the id (unique identifier, often the primary key) of the persistent class

Specified by:

Override this if desired

Returns:

checkClass

protected Class<?> checkClass(Class<?> type)
This does a nice bit of exception handling for us and verifies that this class is valid to perform a DAO operation with

Parameters:
type - class type of the persistent object to check
Returns:
A valid entityClass type resolved to be the same as the ones usable by this DAO

initCaches

protected void initCaches()
Creates all the caches for the current set of persistent types, this should be called in the init for the generic dao being used after persistent classes are loaded

create

public void create(Object object)
Description copied from interface: BasicModifier
Create the object and assign it an id, if the object already has an id then it will be created using that id, if there is no id then one will be assigned to it

Specified by:
create in interface BasicModifier
Parameters:
object - the persistent type object to save (hibernate version must have associated hbm file)

save

public void save(Object object)
Description copied from interface: BasicModifier
Saves the object and transforms it into a persistent object if it is not already one and assigns it an id, if is already persistent then the object is updated

Specified by:
save in interface BasicModifier
Parameters:
object - the persistent type object to save (must have associated hbm file)
